Title: From Warfare to Welfare: A Comparative Study of Combat Trauma Internalization and Institutionalization

This anthropological study aims to develop a comparative framework for understanding how combat trauma is internalized and institutionalized in Israel, the United States, and the Netherlands. Through ethnographic fieldwork, clinical practices research, policy analysis, and discourse analysis, we will examine the roles of military and psychiatric institutions in shaping combat trauma experiences. Our research will shed light on the conflicting values and perceptions of ethnicity that influence veteran care, and identify key problems in current healthcare approaches.

The expected outcomes of this project include informing policy and healthcare reform, advancing studies in biopolitics and medicalization, and deepening our understanding of war-related suffering internalization. By centering the experiences of veterans and clinicians, this project will contribute significantly to our knowledge of combat trauma institutionalization and the ways in which ethnicity intersects with military and psychiatric institutions. Ultimately, our research seeks to improve care for veterans and promote a more nuanced understanding of the complexities of combat trauma.

Title: From Warfare to Welfare: A Comparative Study of How Combat Trauma is Internalized and Institutionalized

This interdisciplinary research project undertakes a comparative study of combat trauma in Israel, the United States, and the Netherlands, examining how it is internalized by veterans and institutionalized by military and psychiatric institutions. Through an innovative combination of ethnographic fieldwork, clinical practices research, policy analysis, and discourse analysis, this project aims to develop a comprehensive framework for understanding the complex dynamics of combat trauma.

The study will shed light on how conflicting values and perceptions of ethnicity shape the experiences of veterans in military and psychiatric institutions, and how these institutions respond to war-related suffering. By analyzing the institutionalization of combat trauma, this project expects to identify key problems in veteran care, inform policy and healthcare reform, and advance our understanding of biopolitics and medicalization.

The project's significance lies in its focus on the institutionalization of combat trauma, the experiences of veterans with ethnicity in military and psychiatric institutions, and the resistance to clinical illness models. The expected outcomes will have a direct impact on policy and healthcare, ultimately improving the lives of veterans. By targeting veterans and clinicians, this project will provide a nuanced understanding of combat trauma, informing more effective care and support systems. Ultimately, this research will contribute to a deeper understanding of war-related suffering and its internalization, informing strategies for promoting welfare and well-being among veterans.
